In this study, fluorine (F) modified cerium oxide (Fx-Ce) catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method to investigate the impact of fluorine species on CeO2 catalyst for toluene oxidation. Compared to bared CeO2, the catalysis activity of Fx-Ce was further improved. The temperature of toluene conversion (T90% and T50%) for F3-Ce decreased by ΔT90% = 30°C and ΔT50% = 15°C, respectively. The characterizations of H2-TPR, O2-TPD, Raman, XPS certified that there was more chemisorbed oxygen, oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ ions on the F3-Ce than bared CeO2. DFT calculations demonstrated that the formation energy of oxygen vacancy on F3-Ce is reduced by surface-florine, which promotes the formation of oxygen vacancy. Meanwhile, Toluene-TPD indicated that fluorine-doping increased the adsorption capacity of toluene on CeO2. According to the above-mentioned results, F3-Ce has higher oxygen vacancy concentration, more active oxygen, and larger toluene adsorption capacity. Thus it has the optimal catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fluorine modified Surface fluorine Formation energy Toluene oxidation 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) have posed an enormous threat to both the environment and human health [1,2]. Over the years, many techniques have been developed to eliminate VOCs, including catalytic oxidation, plasma decomposition, adsorption, incineration, absorption, etc. [3–5]. Among these techniques, catalytic oxidation is an energy-efficient and well-established technique that can reduce VOCs emissions without secondary pollution [6–9]. Noble metal (such as Pt, Pd, Ag) based catalysts have been widely used during the past decades and have an excellent low temperature activity for VOCs oxidation [10–12]. However, the disadvantages of this technology such as high cost, low stability, and the catalysts were easily poisoned by chlorine and sulfur limit the potential of broader application [13]. Due to the low cost, high stability and activity for VOCs oxidation, transition metal oxide catalysts are considered as the most potential catalysts [14]. More recently, various transition metal oxides were designed for VOCs oxidation, such as cerium-based [15], copper-based [16], manganese-based [17], and nickel-based catalysts [18]. Among them, CeO2 has always exhibited excellent performance for VOCs oxidation since its high oxygen mobility, excellent redox potential of the Ce4+/Ce3+ couple and electron-hole exchange interaction [19–21]. However, since the limitations of self-structure and physicochemical properties, bared CeO2 exhibits unsatisfactory performance in medium-low temperature range for the degradation of toluene [22–24]. The methods of metallic element modification [25] or developing novel preparation methods (co-precipitation method [26], impregnation method [27], and so on) are used to further improve the catalytic activity of CeO2. Reddy et al. [28] reported that Ce0.7Mn0.3O2–δ catalysts had higher concentration of oxygen defects and active oxygen than CeO2, which is a primary factor of better catalytic performance. Shen et al. [29] found that MnOx–CeO2 catalyst synthesized by the modified co-precipitation method had more active oxygen and Mn4+ species than the catalysts obtained by sol-gel method, leading to a better catalytic performance for formaldehyde oxidation. Meanwhile, non-metal modification has also used to enhance the catalytic performance and has made considerable progress. You et al. [30] obtained Ce10Px/Ti catalysts by impregnation method. The result revealed that phosphorus-doping enhances the concentration of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen, which promotes the transfer of surface oxygen and the regeneration of active sites. Hwang et al. [31] synthesized Si-modified CeO2 by co-precipitation method and claimed that SiCe catalyst was mainly attributed to the larger specific surface area, increase of oxygen vacancy and chemisorbed oxygen for the more Ce3+, which was improved by the addition of silicon. As is known to all, fluorine can facilitate electronic and structural properties of catalysts due to its strong electronegativity. For example, Wang et al. [32] prepared F-doped TiO2 catalysts by sol-gel method. They found both surface and lattice fluorine exist on the catalyst. The surface fluorine adsorbed on the surface of TiO2 in the form of Ti–F can generate more •OH radicals. The lattice fluorine replace the oxygen atoms of TiO2 to generate oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ by the charge compensation effect ((1-x)TiO2 + xF− → Ti3+ xTi4+ 1-xO2− 2-xF− x + x/2O2−). Deng et al. [33] obtained CeTiF catalysts by co-precipitation method. The result revealed that fluorine atom replaces the O in Ce–O–Ti or Ti–O–Ti bonds to produce more oxygen vacancies, and improve the specific surface area and redox property. Based on the above research, we are curious about the effect of fluoride on CeO2 for the oxidation of VOCs, and there are few reports on this aspect. Hence, we aim at developing a novel catalyst for VOCs oxidation, and further study the underlying mechanism of F on CeO2. In this study, fluorine (F) modified cerium oxide (Fx-Ce) catalysts with different amount of F were synthesized by co-precipitation method, and employed for toluene oxidation. The characterizations of XRD, BET, SEM, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, Toluene-TPD and DFT calculation were utilized to analyze the catalysts. Meanwhile, the stability tests were conducted on the best Fx-Ce catalyst to evaluate its feasibility for VOCs oxidation. This paper aims to study the effect of fluorine on the structure and catalytic performance of Fx-Ce. We expect this study could provide some inspiration in the design of Ce-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Bared CeO2 and F-modified CeO2 catalysts are prepared by co-precipitation method. Specifically, 0.01 mol Ce(NO3)3•6H2O and a certain amount of NH4F (molar ratio of F/Ce = 0.01, 0.03 and 0.05) were dissolved into 100 ml deionized water. Subsequently, NH3•H2O was dropped into the mixture until pH = 10 and stirred for 2 h. Then, the solution was filtrated and washed for three times with deionized water. Finally, the Fx-Ce (x = 0.01, 0.03 and 0.05) catalysts were obtained by drying under vacuum at 110°C and calcining at 400°C for 4 h. As a comparison, pure CeO2 is obtained using the same method in the absence of NH4F. F3-Ce-u catalyst was obtained by stability test of F3-Ce at 340 °C for 50 h. 2.2 Characterization, catalyst evaluation and DFT calculation The details of this section were provided in supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalysts were tested for toluene oxidation in the temperature range of 160–380 °C, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . It was observed that the fluorine-doping has a positive impact on toluene oxidation. The activity of catalysts followed an order of F5-Ce < CeO2 < F1-Ce < F3-Ce. The temperature of F3-Ce catalyst achieving 50% (T50) and 90% (T90) conversion was 218 °C and 306 °C (Table S1), respectively, which is far below that of CeO2. Meanwhile, F3-Ce also exhibits better catalytic performance at medium-low temperature than Ce-based catalysts in other literature (Table S2). These results indicated that a certain amount of fluorine doping could increase the oxidation efficiency of toluene over CeO2. 3.2 Structural analysis The XRD patterns of CeO2 and Fx-Ce catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks at 28°, 33°, 47°, 59°, 69°, 77° and 79° correspond to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) planes of the cubic phase CeO2 [34]. The main peaks of Fx-Ce catalysts are well consistent with the cubic phase CeO2 and there was no significant shift in the location of peaks. Moreover, no new characteristic reflections for fluorine or fluorine-containing phases are found in XRD patterns of Fx-Ce (Fig. S1), meaning that fluorine does not change the crystalline phase of CeO2. The SEM diagram (Fig. S2) also shows that F-doping has no effect on the morphology of CeO2. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of all catalysts have been characterized by the BET-BJH models. The results were summarized in Fig. S3 and Table 1 . It could be clearly seen that all catalysts show the type-IV isotherms with similar mesoporous architecture, which can also be confirmed by the pore parameters (Fig. S3b) [35]. In Table 1, it could be seen that the addition of F (<3%) has little effect on the specific surface area. However, it can be found that the specific surface area will be decreased by the addition of excessive fluorine (F5-Ce), which may result from the collapse of pore structure by the addition of excessive fluorine [35,36]. Meanwhile, one can see that the average pore size increases with the increase of the content of F-doping for Fx-Ce catalysts, and the pore volume of F5-Ce is the smallest. Combined with the pore size distributions (Fig. S3b), there are fewer small pores below 5 nm for F5-Ce and the pore size is mainly concentrated around 10 nm. The phenomenon may be caused by the collapse of the pore structure due to the presence of excessive fluorine, resulting in the larger average pore size and the decrease of pore volume [37]. It is known that Raman spectra is widely used to investigate the phase composition of catalysts. As presented in Fig. 3 , the peak at 465 cm−1 is regarded as F2g of ceria fluorite-type structure. The second peak at 600 cm−1 is attributed to defect-induced (ID) mode associated with the oxygen vacancies due to the presence of Ce3+ [38]. As reported, the relative ratio of ID/IF2g is positively correlated with the oxygen vacancy concentration on Ce-based catalysts [39]. As listed in Table 1, the oxygen vacancy concentration follows the order of F3-Ce > F1-Ce > CeO2 > F5-Ce, indicating that the addition of fluorine is conducive to the generation of surface oxygen vacancy on CeO2. Generally, higher oxygen vacancy concentration is more conducive to toluene oxidation, that is why F3-Ce possesses the best catalytic performance. Surface element information over the CeO2 and F3-Ce are studied by XPS (Fig. 4 ) and the related results are listed in Table 2 . The F 1s spectra (Fig. 4a) for F3-Ce catalyst contains two peaks. One located at 684.4 eV is assigned to F− ions adsorbed on CeO2 surface (named as surface F), and another at 688.2 eV is attributed to the F− ions incorporated into CeO2 lattice (named as lattice F) [40,41]. These results indicate that F species exist in two states on Fx-Ce, and the surface F is dominant species on the CeO2. For the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 4b), eight peaks can be observed [42]. Two peaks at 884.6 and 903.1 eV are ascribed to the Ce3+ ions (named as v2 and u2). The other peaks at 882.6, 889.3, 898.6, 901.1, 907.7 and 916.9 eV correspond to the Ce4+ ions (named as v1, v3, v4, u1, u3 and u4). The percentage of Ce3+ ions on different catalysts are calculated by the peaks area of Ce 3d spectra (Table 2). The percentage of Ce3+ species in F3-Ce is 27.71%, which is more than that of CeO2 (24.35%). This indicates that the addition of a low content of fluorine is beneficial to the generation of Ce3+. As reported, the formation of one oxygen vacancy corresponds to the generation of double Ce3+, indicating the amount of Ce3+ is positively related to the concentration of oxygen vacancy on CeO2 surface [43]. Additionally, Fig. 4c displays the O 1s spectra, which has two apparent peaks. The peak at 531.0 eV corresponds to chemisorbed oxygen (masked as Oα). The second peak at 529.1 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen (labelled as Oβ) [44]. The amount of Oα species is positively correlated with the oxygen vacancy concentration, which is mainly adsorbed at oxygen vacancy [45,46]. The ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) is used to represent the concentration of active oxygen (Table 2). The calculation results demonstrate that the Oα on F3-Ce (33.8%) is higher than that on the CeO2 (27.8%). Liao et al. [47] discussed the role of oxygen species for toluene oxidation, and they believed that Oα species played a key role in the reaction. Thus, the F3-Ce catalyst, which contains more Oα specices, is more active for toluene oxidation. The F3-Ce catalyst after 50 h long-term stability test (340 °C) were characterized by XPS (Fig. 4) and XRD (Fig. 5 ). The relevant results are shown in Table 2. Compared with the F3-Ce catalyst, the relative content of Ce3+ and Oα of F3-Ce-u (obtained by stability test of F3-Ce at 340 °C for 50 h) is slightly decreased, which implies that F3-Ce-u may lose some surface oxygen and oxygen vacancies [25]. Meanwhile, it could be seen the atomic ratio of F remains unchanged, which also means that F can stably exist on CeO2 after the 50 h long-term stability test (340 °C). In Fig. 5, the diffraction peaks of F3-Ce and F3-Ce-u have no noticeable change, indicating that the stability test does not affect the phase and particle size of catalysts [48]. In order to confirm the results of Raman and XPS above, DFT calculations were performed to access the underlying source of the difference in the formation energy of oxygen vacancy. Based on the careful analysis of the experiment results, an underlying relation may exist between catalytic performance and oxygen vacancy. From the above XPS data, it could be seen that fluorine in F3-Ce exists in the form of surface fluorine and lattice fluorine, so our theoretical calculations will be carried out around them. In order to understand the effect of fluorine on CeO2, three kinds of slab models have been established, including CeO2 (111), lattice-F-CeO2 (111), and surface-F-CeO2 (111) model [49], as shown in Fig. 6 . According to the results, the doping sites of F have a significant influence on the formation of oxygen vacancy. For CeO2, the formation energy of oxygen vacancy (Eov) is 2.2 eV. When F is doped into the crystal lattice of CeO2, the Eov on the surface of the catalyst is basically unchanged. It is worth noting that when F is doped on the surface of CeO2, the oxygen vacancy formation energy is reduced to 0.9 eV, which means that it is easier to form oxygen vacancies on F-CeO2 (111) surface. Meanwhile, we have performed bader charge analysis to confirm the charge difference between these models [50]. As shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S4, for lattice-F-CeO2 (111), it could be seen that the lattice F only interacts with the Ce who connected to fluorine directly and has little effect on the surrounding Ce and O. It will not destroy the charge balance of CeO2 system, which also corresponds to the similar oxygen vacancy formation energy on CeO2 and lattice-F-CeO2 (111). In addition, compared with the lattice F, surface F destroys the charge balance of the CeO2 system. There is a strong interaction between surface F and the Ce who connected to it directly, which leads to the charge imbalance on the adjacent Ce and O and weakens the Ce-O bond (2.368 Å→2.456 Å). According to the above results, we infer that the interaction (the charge imbalance) between surface F and the Ce atom brings about a stretch to the neighboring Ce-O bond. Moreover, it makes oxygen vacancy form easier because of the weakening effect on the Ce-O bond strength. However, the fluorine in the lattice has no obvious effect on the formation of oxygen vacancy; thus fluorine on the surface may play a key role in F3-Ce. Given the central role of oxygen vacancy in catalyst, F3-Ce is expected to achieve better performance than CeO2, which fits well with the toluene oxidation results. 3.3 Surface properties analysis The reducibility of all catalysts was studied by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 8 , the reduction peaks over the catalysts are fitted into three temperature ranges, corresponding to the reduction of surface (100–400 °C), subsurface (400–600 °C) and bulk (>600 °C) oxygen species, respectively [35]. The area of the reduction peak is positively related to the the consumption of hydrogen [51,52]. Generally, the surface and subsurface oxygen is more active than bulk oxygen [46], thus we integrated the reduction peak area (< 600°C). The relevant data is listed in Table 1. The reduction peak area of all catalysts follows the order of F5-Ce < CeO2 < F1-Ce < F3-Ce, indicating that a proper amount of F-doping can increase the amount of reducible species (surface/subsurface oxygen). Meanwhile, F3-Ce has the lowest original reduction temperature among all catalysts, which means it has the strongest redox property. O2-TPD profiles and peak area of all catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 9 . The desorption peaks are divided into three categories, namely α (<200 °C), β (200–400 °C) and γ (>400 °C) groups, which could be ascribed to the desorption of the physisorbed oxygen, chemisorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen [53,54]. As depicted in Fig. 9b, among the four catalysts, F3-Ce possesses far larger amount of both the physisorbed oxygen (α) and chemisorbed oxygen (β), which fits with the results of H2-TPR and XPS. Moreover, the desorption temperature of chemisorbed oxygen of F3-Ce catalyst is lower than that of other catalysts, revealing that the addition of fluorine enhances the activation ability of oxygen species and the reactivity of chemisorbed oxygen on F3-Ce is higher than that on other catalysts [48,55]. Compared with surface active oxygen species (α, β), the lattice oxygen also participates in the reaction, but its activity is lower than that of surface active oxygen due to its high stability [47]. It has been reported that toluene oxidation on Ce-based catalysts processed by L–H mechanism at low temperature (<300 °C) and MVK mechanism at high temperature. When the temperature is higher than 300 °C, the reaction follows the MVK mechanism. It may be that the lattice oxygen plays a major role in the reaction at high temperature. Meanwhile, from Fig. 9a, the surface adsorbed oxygen species has been removed after 330 °C, which also means that lattice oxygen will also be one of th factors affecting the catalyst activity [47]. However, the activity of lattice oxygen is lower than that of surface active oxygen species, which may result in a slower conversion rate. This also corresponds to the increasingly smaller activity gap between CeO2 and F3-Ce in Fig. 1. In summary, higher concentration of active oxygen (α, β) and excellent oxygen adsorption and activation ability are conducive to toluene oxidation, thus F3-Ce has the best low-temperature oxidation activity. The previous studies have demonstrated that the adsorption performances of toluene play a key role in toluene oxidation. Herein Toluene-TPD was performed to study the adsorption performances of all catalysts. As presented in Fig. 10 , the desorption peaks at 100–200 °C and 200–500 °C are attributed to weak adsorbed and strong adsorbed toluene, respectively [56]. The desorption peak area can indirectly correspond to the adsorption capacity of toluene. The desorption area of toluene between 100 °C and 200 °C can be ranked as follows: F5-Ce < CeO2 < F1-Ce < F3-Ce. Meanwhile, it also follows this rule from 200 °C to 500 °C. F3-Ce has the largest desorption peak area, which indicates that a small amount of F-doping is beneficial to the adsorption of toluene on CeO2. Caiting Li [57] reported that toluene is adsorbed on the active oxygen of oxygen vacancies, which fits well with the results of H2-TPR and Raman above. F3-Ce has the most active oxygen species and oxygen vacancies, providing more adsorption sites for toluene. 3.4 Stability and water effect on F3-Ce In industrial application, catalytic stability is one of the key indicators to evaluate the catalytic performance. In the experiment, the stability of F3-Ce at different temperatures was tested. As presented in Fig. 11 a, it could be seen that F3-Ce has excellent catalytic stability for toluene oxidation. The conversion remained unchanged at 240 °C (80%) and 340 °C (95%) for 50 h. Therefore, F3-Ce has a good prospect for practical application. Water is a factor that must be considered in the treatment of VOCs, thereby the effect of water on toluene oxidation over the F3-Ce catalyst is tested. As presented in Fig. 11b, the F3-Ce catalyst is tested at 340 °C with 5 vol% H2O. One can see that the toluene conversion decreases rapidly from 94% to 88% when 5 vol% H2O is introduced, and remains unchanged at 88% for 24 h. When 5 vol% H2O is removed from the reaction, the toluene conversion is restored to the original level. Meanwhile, the slight decrease in activity is mainly due to the competitive adsorption of water molecules and toluene on the surface of catalyst [51,58]. In summary, the slight decrease in activity and its recoverability indicates that the F3-Ce catalyst has good water resistance and reversible effect. 3.5 Possible promotional mechanism analysis According to the results obtained above and literatures, the possible promotional mechanism of toluene oxidation on F3-Ce is proposed in Fig. 12 . The surface F on CeO2 makes the bond length of neighbouring Ce-O longer and weak the Ce-O bond, making it easier for the formation of oxygen vacancy. This leads to more oxygen vacancies on F3-Ce. Meanwhile, F-doping is beneficial to the adsorption of toluene. The reaction of toluene oxidation occurs by the combined actions of the above two aspects. As shown in F 1s XPS and theoretical calculation, two types of fluorine species existed on F3-Ce, and the surface fluorine is dominant species, which results in large amounts of surface oxygen vacancies for the adsorption-activation of oxygen molecule (O 1s XPS, Raman) and improves the oxygen mobility. Toluene-TPD shows that F3-Ce has a higher toluene capacity than CeO2. Therefore, the improvements in oxygen adsorption-activation and toluene capacity both contribute to the superior catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. 4 Conclusion In summary, CeO2 and F-modified CeO2 catalysts are synthesized by co-precipitation method for toluene oxidation. The characterizations prove that F3-Ce catalyst has higher low-temperature reducibility, higher toluene capacity, more active oxygen species and oxygen vacancies due to the more Ce3+ ions induced by the strong interaction between F and Ce. As a result, F3-Ce has the optimum performance for toluene oxidation with conversions of 50% and 90% at 218 °C and 306 °C, respectively. Moreover, the F3-Ce catalyst also exhibited excellent water resistance and stability in the 50 h stability test, meaning that it is a potential catalyst for toluene oxidation in industrial application. coredata.dc:description: In this study, fluorine (F) modified cerium oxide (Fx-Ce) catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method to investigate the impact of fluorine species on CeO2 catalyst for toluene oxidation. Compared to bared CeO2, the catalysis activity of Fx-Ce was further improved. The temperature of toluene conversion (T90% and T50%) for F3-Ce decreased by ΔT90% = 30°C and ΔT50% = 15°C, respectively. The characterizations of H2-TPR, O2-TPD, Raman, XPS certified that there was more chemisorbed oxygen, oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ ions on the F3-Ce than bared CeO2. DFT calculations demonstrated that the formation energy of oxygen vacancy on F3-Ce is reduced by surface-florine, which promotes the formation of oxygen vacancy. Meanwhile, Toluene-TPD indicated that fluorine-doping increased the adsorption capacity of toluene on CeO2. According to the above-mentioned results, F3-Ce has higher oxygen vacancy concentration, more active oxygen, and larger toluene adsorption capacity. Thus it has the optimal catalytic activity for toluene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of surface fluorine species on CeO2 catalyst for toluene oxidation
